content.description: Stand start highball double arete pillar with a sketch landing. Awesome problem.
content.location: Between the snake pit and the bar traverse.

content.description: Pull bulge beneath the sport climbs.
content.location: Pit to the left at the base of the sport climbs.

content.description:
Brilliant sloper problem. SDS all the way to the right side, with right right hand around the corner on a good crimp. Move left onto the lip and use strategic heel hooks to stay on the lip. Just before the "death pit" move up and right to a good rail to mantle onto the slab. Top out.

EDIT: This is now the "half-glassed" version of the Full Glass Lipper V6. The full glass follows the entire lip over a landing of logs and tops out at the top of the lip.
content.location: A prominent boulder just downhill and to the left of the three bolted sport climbs if you have your back to the river. Pretty obvious lip.

content.description:
The full extension to the half glass lipper. We built a landing over the death pit at the end of the climb with logs. If the logs are gone, consider rebuilding a landing before attempting.

SDS low with a right hand crimp around corner and left hand on a crimp. Bump left hand to a larger hold, and begin working your way left and up the lip. Traverse the entire lip and top out at the very end/top. V6 if you stay true to the lip and avoid any tempting holds up above the lip.

Solid rock with few fractures! Shouldn't have much breakage occur on this one.

WATER - I cleaned the line, but noticed that it does stay wet for several days longer than the other rocks after rain due to the moss on the cliff right above the boulder. Just a heads up!
content.location: Directly to the left if facing the sport climbs.

climbs.name: Factotum
climbs.fa: FFA: Chris Summit, ca. 2006? (toprope)   FA: Brian S and John (sport lead)

content.description: Start on a large rock. Make a committing move across a chasm onto the slick slab start. Clip a couple of bolts before reaching a large triangle hold. Then embark on short but intense crux section. An easy (but dirty) section will bring you to the anchors.
content.location: 20ft left of Bar Fly and just left of a dihedral.

content.description: Sit start in the middle of the face on a jug and traverse up and left to the arete and top out.
content.location: If your facing toward the sport climbsthis boulder is located downhill (toward the river) and right of the unnamed V7 double highball arete.

content.description: Traverse the face along the left side of Bar Rock around the corner if your looking at the sport climbs. There is a large fig tree that sometimes blocks the base of this wall. Thin edges over a rocky landing. Start on the right side of the wall near the arete and pull on and traverse left over a small pit till you reach a ledge where you can stand and take your hands off the wall.

The right set of obvious bolts, good climbing with positive holds, route is  5.5 after the 3rd or 4th bolt so a little soft for the grade IMO. rock is super solid, not crumbly like some routes at the quarry, and its nice to be right next to the water on hot days!
content.location: Just up stream from mammoth bar bouldering located right on the waters edge!

content.description: Left set of bolts on the main face, bolt line slightly traverses right and then shares anchors with Bar Fly.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt chain anchor
content.location: Just upstream from the mammoth bar boulders, this face will be on your left, cant miss the bolts
